Mallari (2023) was considered a historical thriller film but instead, we got a horror fantasy film that somehow got recognized by Warner Bros. One thing I must admit is that the film has great spectacular production sets & designs. And it's such a shame that it was implemented for this horror film with cheap jump scares and unnecessary time-traveling twist to make the premise so interesting. I wished the story should've been like GomBurZa. I actually do not know that this film is "loosely" based on Fr. Juan Severino Mallari, who is the first documented serial killer from the Philippines. I said "loosely based" because the film even adds two unnecessary fictional characters related to Mallari. The Mallari trio is played by none other than Piolo Pascual. It is very impressive for one actor to play three roles in this film, but his "present" Mallari performance was so unconvincing throughout the film, compared to his two roles. It would've been nice if Piolo just played the actual Mallari, not this make-believe storytelling.The story is complicated and it makes me wonder what are they trying to tell other than Mallari's actions for his killings. I can't get enough about this time-travelling twist. It creates a turmoil to its story that I can't describe and say anything positive about it.If Mallari take the GomBurZa approach as a proper historical thriller, it would've been a great film. But unfortunately, the film shall take its path for being a convoluting mess with great visuals and production design.

Came for Piolo, stayed for absolutely everyone but Piolo.First off, the writing for the climax scene was pretty good, with Janella Salvador, JC Santos, and Geraldine Villamil (Mariang Capac) doing a lot of the heavy lifting. Piolo Pascual, and overall the writing of the main character Jonathan, I think, is a main weak point of this movie for me. Piolo was not believable as a doctor or as a filmmaker (maybe a little bit as a serial killer), his character is weakly fleshed out outside of the obsession with some vague thing with the house and its connection to Janella, and the moustache and glasses are just laughable. I was honestly more captivated by Lucas and the other mga mambabarang.Overall, needed paring down -- some roles were superficial yet occupied too much screen time (cough the kids and I mean all the kids, and the policemen cough) -- should imo have focused on Severino Mallari more, and not used godawful CG for old Gloria Diaz.

i would have written my review way earlier had it not been for the jumble of mess this movie turned my thoughts into. well, at least it is loyal to that much.this movie was lacklustre at the very least, and mediocre at best. apart from its borderline misogynistic and transphobic elements, its ambition to sprinkle in a little bit of everything was quite disappointing in its delivery (especially the sci-fi bit). it came out rather messily. although history-centred films are rarely ever 100% accurate to their source material, adding in the astral projection bullshit just did not cut it for me. i think they should have just focused on fr. severino mallari alone; i think it would have done better as a psychological thriller. i felt more intensely from the jumpscares than the fight scenes, or even the supposedly emotional ones. in short, this movie did not work for me.

Honestly, in my opinion, the only good thing about this movie was Piolo's top-notch acting. While I understand that making horror movies is one of the hardest genres, it's not surprising when a Filipino horror movie turns out really bad. I wish it hadn't been this disappointing though. They clearly prioritized cinematography, but in a horror film, the horror aspect should never be overlooked. The pacing of some scenes and the editing were more painful to watch than the priest's killing scenes. On a positive note, I appreciated the fresh take on the famous story of the first serial killer. However, the storytelling was weak, and some elements didn't make complete sense, seemingly just to fulfill the director's vision.

If I were to give this film an honest rating, I'd say it's a 2.2 out of 5. Why the .2? Gawa nung "Amoy kiffy!" EME. Pero I can say that they tried the best they could for this movie naman. Okay 'yung actors, lalo na si Piolo at JC. Mahirap gumanap ng apat sa iisang movie. Tapos kay JC, very galing talaga mag act, very natural. The storyline for me is OK. I can see why they didn't stick with just retelling the past. Maybe because of lacking history documents? So, I get it naman. For the missing points naman, siguro I was bummed out with the dialogues? The actors were not the problem, it was the corny ass script. There were times the scenes were just unnatural and forced. Tapos 'yung camera works, ok ok siya but may scenes na pwede baguhin 'yung angles. And then the CGI. I mean, improving? Siguro if I wasn't paying attention with the whole movie and just paying attention to Piolo, siguro hindi ko mapapansin eh. Pero may times na it's giving laughable instead of spooky. Overall, I enjoyed the movie.

It‚Äôs been a while that i‚Äôve seen a decent Filipino horror movie and I would say this one doesn‚Äôt disappoint. A pretty good storytelling and a very nice acting by Papa P (ü§£ü§£ü§£ i refused to call him any name otherwise, my aunts will be so proud)SFX aint that good but not bad either. Also, the song by the end are a pretty banger. The only thing is that if you‚Äôre not filipino and watched this, high chance you‚Äôll be confused about the malignos and stuff. The folklore wasn‚Äôt explained enough and some people might not get the correlation between the supernatural beings and the chick being passed on to another person. It‚Äôs one of those movies where you have to search them by the end of watching it just to gets the supernatural beings much better but it doesn‚Äôt really affect the plot that much. Still a good watch and actually kept my attention from start to the end.

"Mallari" was intriguing, bold and underwhelming.Seemingly a partly fictional, partly real life inspired account on the Philippines' first documented serial killer, Severino Mallari (keep in mind when! :O). I thought there's some cool stuff in the concept/ideas department, throughout. Really liked the structure too.Well, Piolo Pascual was pretty good with his various (quite well distinguished) roles. Several other neat contributions from the cast, particularly from JC Santos.I thought the movie went a bit over its head, to be honest. Both plot and execution-wise. On a more "focused" perspective, the plot has a few glaring plotholes and some underwhelming execution (particularly where action and horror are involved, for the most part).Several different approaches: some better, some worse (personally, I didn't enjoy some of the jumpscare technique with the editing). Two bigger scenes... one head-on, another avoided.The plot/story, while well structured and definitely intriguing, on a closer look, should feel quite shallow in a few regards.The latter stages were reasonable, particularly again structure-wise.I didn't particularly enjoy the ending, though it should be ok-ish (if you enjoy the "reason"; I didn't and I missed some wickedness, for sure).Overall, an ambitious and interesting movie that I felt went for more than it could manage, though it's certainly understandable that you should go for it ^_^ I felt the plot could've been stronger, particularly around the "origin/reason" and the execution could also have been better. The horror elements felt lacking, particularly in several (avoided) scenes. But I think they did pretty great in creating something quite interesting around the "main story" element. I think this can totally be a 6 too but I'll fall back to the reasonable 5 for this one.

Mallari tackles the intersectionality of religion, faith, folklore, culture, history, and science. Spanning three different timelines, I think it was presented pretty seamlessly, though it could have been executed better. I think this performance if Piolo Pascual is a bit lukewarm. Despite their short appearances in the film, JC Santos and Janella Salvador had great performances here.For the most part, it was a bit sad that the film leaned more into the cheap jump scare horror when it could have capitalized on the opportunities brought about by religion and humanity. However, it would take a certain awareness and attention to detail to realize that there is a deeper horror embedded in the film - that love is a curse, and the lengths that a person will go through for the person they love, regardless of the consequences they face in return.

This one is ambitious in the sense that there's a lot of concepts going on here. Kinda ambitious like Kathryn Bernardo's and Dolly De Leon's A Very Good Girl BUT this one, though in a different genre, did it better. The plot was kind of OA but my points are for the actors and cinematography. They're really good for Filipino movies. I've never seen Piolo this way and I love the range. JC was also great in that bolo scene.

One of the best Filipino horror movies, especially in recent times. The twist they did to the actual myth around Mallari's killing was smart. The mysterious and eerie feeling from start to finish was also great and Piolo Pascual was phoenomenal in the starring role.

a horror film that only relies on jumpscares and gore to scare you isn't really a good horror film, no?i had high expectations for this and they were just not met. the plot was all over the place, the dialogue trying to sound deep even when they were in the present time, the distracting CGI, the time traveling. i can go on but i think the main issue was the film failed to just focus on one thing and flesh out the story from there. the main plot about a priest who's a serial killer is interesting enough but they just had to add a bunch of other elements that resulted to a convoluted story. it's frustrating to think about what could have been.

Like, men are so stupid and unreasonable. Jonathan, darling, I get it‚Äîit's Janella Salvador, but really? Father, why is the wig weave showing like that? (Tatak Pinoy films to have bad wigs, I said what I said). JC Santos, that nose acting, bro. I'm so frigging tired. I don't even watch horror, but those jumpscares did nothing to me‚Äîthey are just jumpscares and didn't add anything to the plot.I think in this day and age, we would all rather die than be a maligno. I also would like to point out that he became a werewolf at some point, and the cinematography used shadows‚Äîand the shadows were cheap in form. I guess I want to say in the end, Filipino films' bare minimum is moving in the right direction.
